text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Jordan says it reschedules $450 million debt owed to the Paris Club of official creditors.
- Kuwaitis in favour of normalisation with Jordan and Yemen.
- Difficulties face mobilising a majority of deputies to hold an extraordinary session of parliament; official worry of parliament being used for election campaigning.
- King Hussein says Jordan will continue to be a force for conciliation in the region.
- Planning Ministry says the United States is serious about increasing its aid to Jordan and suggests it could be in form of new grants.
- State Audit Bureau cites 2,000 violations related to public money by state bodies and ministries in 1996.
- Israel to open a consulate in Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba soon.
- Jordan to issue new passports in the third quarter of the year.

- Jordanian-Palestinian-Egyptian summit expected within a few days; Jordan's foreign minister neither confirms nor denies reports of the meeting, but says Jordan is awaiting the results of a mission by an Egyptian envoy to Israel.
- Jordan refuses to discuss joining a defence pact with Israel.
- King Hussein says will stand by the Palestinians until they regain their national rights.
- Jordan calls on Kuwait to reopen its embassy and resume air flights.
- Eleven parties unify ranks against the new press laws.
